newsitem.title: INDIA: BMW plans India launch of 5-series cars.
newsitem.headline: BMW plans India launch of 5-series cars.

text.p: German car maker Bayerische Motoren Werke plans to launch its 5-series cars in 1997 in India, where it sees big business potential along with the rest of Asia, chairman Bernd Pischetsrieder said on Tuesday.
"We will be possibly starting within the end of next year manufacture of the middle-class, 5-series model in India," Pischetsrieder told reporters in the Indian capital.

BMW has previously said it wanted to assemble vehicles in India and last month it won Indian government approval to take 51 percent in a joint venture with the Hero group. Other details have not been worked out, company officials said.
Pischetsrieder said BMW's market share in Asia was at its lowest, compared with other regions, adding that there was big scope for its luxury cars.
But he said BMW's strategy was to proceed cautiously.
"Everybody in our industry is concentrating on what we call emerging markets," Pischetsrieder said.
"We as a company clearly think we don't want to dump cars without being able to give technical support," he said. "We are clearly determined to go on the slow, sustainable growth route."
"We are not in a position to say we will sell thousands of cars next year," he added.

Company officials said BMW was likely to launch its 5-series 2.5 litre capacity, diesel-engine cars in India in collaboration with India's Hero group but the amount of the investment had not been finalised with the Indian government.
They said the cars, priced at around $40,000 in the U.S. middle-class market, would qualify for an upper market segment in India where disposable incomes were comparitively lower.
"Our market segment has to be developed," said Luden Paysen, group executive in-charge of emerging markets in BMW's sales division.
BMW is already assembling and selling its motorcycles in India in collaboration with the Hero group.
